how did i get here lol i've had a few friends and met quite a few ladies with pretty large or you could even say huge boobs much bigger then in the video but cup sizes are nonsense, most people think ds or dds are gigantic but their actual not big at all infact the average bra size in the us is dd, the cup size is more determined by your band size not so much really the volume of you breasts so its super confusing and misleading, you could have a bunch of women with the same cup size but the actual busts will vary considerably, so g's can be big or they can be small. comparing them to something like fruit is probably better to illustrate size. all sizes are beautiful and while i personally tend to find larger voluptuous woman very with very large breasts very beautiful its not the norm, from my experience the vast majority of guys actually prefer fairly small to average bust sizes, they often fantasize about slightly large sizes or might find them sexy but not actually prefer them or find them attractive which is kinda sad so i'm surprised the one guy said he liked the girl with g's since most guys would probably be to embarrassed to admit they liked them in public. so the lady with cs in the video is more the ideal size with maybe slightly wider hips and a fuller butt would maybe be closer to the average global preference.
the way they reacted to c made me feel a bit better abt mine bc i always get called flat bc im not a dd at 13 yrs how i hate beauty standards

i'll take this comment section as a platform for ruling out personal shit-bits and my questions in that regard, so please take the following with a pinch'a salt! here i go:
what is it with koreans and big booba?
i don't mean to say, that this was an explicit factor for korean people.
but i noticed, that korean artworks are more explicit about ideal representations, so it might be all-that, only.
i'm just sooo fed up with that absolute display of a correct majority or quasi-orthographical approach of the korean culture.
it shows little regret in "apparently unending excess", imo.
i can simply already picture the resulting conceit of "having to be correct/normal" and the painfully fatal resolutions made by applying all that without visible regrets.
i have never been to korea, so i might simply have a bad source for my references here, as well.
what's your take on that?
